questiontext.text:
Select all the equations below which are linear in the variables \(x_{1}\), \(x_{2}\), and \(x_{3}\),

where \(h\) and \(k\) are constants.

generalfeedback.text:
A linear equation in the variables \(x_{1}\), \(x_{2}\), and \(x_{3}\) is an equation of the form:

\(a_{1}x_{1} + a_{2}x_{2} + a_{3}x_{3} = d\)

where \(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\) and \(d\) are real (or complex) numbers i.e. constants.

Therefore if the equation has any term not in this form e.g. \(\sin(x_{2}), \log(x_{1}), x_{2}x_{3}, x_{3}^2\) etc. then the equation is non linear.

Remember that if \(a\) is constant then \(a^2\) or \(\sin(a)\) is still a constant and this doesn't necessarily mean the equation is non linear. It is the transformations on the variables which determine if the equation is linear or not.

feedback.text: Linear. This is the standard form for a linear equation. It contains only constant multiples of the variables and a constant term.
Non linear. This is non linear because of the \((x_{1})^3\) and \((x_{2})^2\) terms. To be linear, we can only have variables multiplied by constants, not powers of the variables.
Non linear. This is non linear because of the \(e^{x_{2}}\) term. \(x_{2}\) terms can only be the form \(ax_{2}\) in a linear equation.
Non linear. This is non linear because of the \(x_{1}x_{2}\) term. To be linear, we can only have variables multiplied by constants, not each other.
Non linear. To be linear, we can only have variables multiplied by constants. Hence taking the square root of the variables makes this non linear.
Linear. This is still linear since \(\sin(a)\) and \(\sin(b)\) are just constants, hence all the terms are constant multiples of the variables.
